item.title: Is it possible to suspend Schengen due to Greece? Is it necessary to do so?
item.description:
A recent leak of a Council document proposes a potential suspension of the Schengen system for a duration of up to two years. This proposal stems from what are being termed “systemic deficiencies” in Greece’s management of its external borders, particularly concerning the influx of refugees and migrants. Such a suspension would provide any Schengen country the option to reinstate or implement border controls along their shared internal borders. While it’s unlikely that every Schengen country would exercise this option, it’s anticipated that several would choose to do so, especially given that a number already have active border controls in place...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/is-it-possible-to-suspend-schengen-due-to-greece-is-it-necessary-to-do-so/

item.title: The ECJ has upheld the EU law on relocating asylum-seekers, but some question if it is a Pyrrhic victory.
item.description:
The EU Court Rules on Refugee Relocation: A Pyrrhic Victory? Professor Steve Peers examines the European Court of Justice’s (ECJ) decision regarding the mandatory relocation of asylum-seekers, highlighting the complex interplay between legal effectiveness and political realities. In 2015, facing a significant influx of asylum-seekers, the EU implemented a measure requiring member states to relocate 160,000 individuals from overburdened Italy and Greece. This decision faced resistance, particularly a legal challenge from Slovakia and Hungary, questioning its legal basis and practicality...

item.title: The program in the European Union that allows Syrian refugees in Turkey to seek humanitarian admission.
item.description:
Laura Robbins-Wright PhD Candidate in Government, London School of Economics and Political Science On December 15, 2015, the European Commission put forward a suggestion for a program to offer humanitarian entry to Syrian refugees residing in Turkey. This proposal follows earlier EU initiatives, including a plan to relocate refugees within the EU and a program for resettling refugees from other countries. It also builds upon an action plan from October 2015 and a more recent decision to give €3 billion to a Refugee Facility designed to better coordinate aid for Syrian refugees in Turkey...

item.title: Assessing the Legal Implications of the EU/Turkey Refugee Deal
item.description:
Steve Peers analyzes the legal and political implications of the recent EU-Turkey agreement on refugees. The agreement, while legally controversial, aims to address the refugee crisis and restore order. A key point of contention is the return of migrants arriving in Greece to Turkey. While the agreement states this will be done in accordance with international law, returning all migrants without considering individual circumstances raises concerns about collective expulsion, a violation of EU and international law...

item.title: Imprison them: the suggestion to revise the EU's Returns Directive
item.description:
Steve Peers, Professor of Law, University of Essex The EU’s Returns Directive, established to manage irregular migration by non-EU citizens, mandates that Member States issue return decisions to unauthorized individuals and enforce their removal. While the Directive allows for voluntary departure periods, it also outlines rules for detention and entry bans. Initially considered lenient by migrant support groups, the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) has since interpreted the Directive more broadly...
